entry.title: Re: How to check authroization header in iFlow
entry.content:
There are a few things to consider:

  • standard authorization/Authorization header (both contain the same value) is hidden by default for security purposes, but you can pass its value via content modifier to a custom header or property to make it visible
  • Remember to assign Data Type as java.lang.String, otherwise, it may contain unwanted values like org.apache.camel.converter.stream.InputStreamCache or org.apache.camel.converter.stream.ByteArrayInputStreamCache
  • Remember to allowlist Authorization in the iFlow runtime configuration
  • Based on my observations, when sender calls via Basic Auth, this value is present, but when the source system calls via OAuth, the header contains empty value. Let me know if you experience the same behavior. In any case, this is sufficient to identify whether the iFlow is called via Basic Auth or OAuth üôÇ

BR

Mateusz

entry.title: Re: Error when updating a user's default layout
entry.content:
Please see details below for your reference on why user encounter the error on "This entry already exists in the following tables 'Document Standards' (RDFL) (ODBC -2035) [Message 131-183]".
  • Before you change the default, other form has been set previously as the default for the current user and all BPs which for example is the Layout 1.
  • Changing the default to for example Layout 2 by using the checkbox as well for "Set as Default for all BPs (for Whom a Default Layout Has Not Been Assigned)" will not override the previous default of Layout 1. To be able to successfully change, user will need to perform the following:
  1. Select the existing default.
  2. Click on Set as Default
  3. Tick the Set as Default for Specified BP
  4. Click Clear button.
  5. Click Update
  6. Click OK
  7. Click OK
  8. Click Update.
  • Then you can now proceed to change the default by using the "Set as Default for all BPs (for Whom a Default Layout Has Not Been Assigned)".

entry.title: Re: I cannot TECO the production order because open outbo...
entry.content:
Someone have done the GI (261 movement) from S4 instead of doing it from the EWM. This cause the issue.
It seems they don't have that mapping for the item type in the Outbound Delivery which is why it is getting stuck in EWM. So what we can do is to delete/cancel the delivery in S/4. 

You can check the deliveries in LIPS table, filter using the Process Order number. 

Reset the Distrib Status of the delivery in S/4 - go to SE37, execute /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS. Input the Outbound Delivery number in IT_DELIVERY_KEYS - VBELN. Then execute. 

Go to VL02N and input the outbound delivery number, then delete

entry.title: Re: OOTB Cache regions issue
entry.content:
Hello SukanyaM

Check if the cache is globally disabled at runtime . Even if properties are the same, CCv2 / dev / stage environments often disable cache via JVM flags or env vars.
check in hac->configuration for properties like xxx.cache.enabled and check if those are true

If it is false, all cache regions exist but are never used, resulting in:

Hits = 0

Misses = 0

Invalidations still increase.

Once you set these properties to true, restart the nodes.

entry.title: Modernize Planning: Universal Hierarchy in SAP Revenue Growth Management for SAP Cloud ERP Customers
entry.content:
1. Navigating Hierarchy Complexity

For emerging consumer products companies, managing customer and product hierarchies is a fundamental challenge for commercial planning. This complexity is inherent to the fast-moving industry, where product portfolios evolve with new launches and discontinuations, customer organizations restructure, and planning cycles need to align with diverse retailer calendars. System administrators and Key Account Managers (KAMs) alike face the challenge of ensuring data consistency, planning accuracy, and operational efficiency amidst these changes. Traditional approaches often lead to manual, error-prone adjustments and a constant game of catch-up.

For customers adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the introduction of the Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management addresses these pain points, offering a time-aware, unified, and streamlined approach to hierarchy management.

 

2. Universal Hierarchy Framework: A Future-Proof Foundation for Revenue Growth

SAP Revenue Growth Management is designed to empower CPG companies with robust tools for account planning, promotion management, and analytics. A critical capability for customers of SAP Cloud ERP is the Universal Hierarchy Framework. We now support both customer and product hierarchies that are time-dependent and versioned‚Äîcapable of consuming SAP Public Cloud's Universal Hierarchy Framework. This means customers now have a future-proof way to manage hierarchies, transforming them as time-aware assets for promotion planning and execution.

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management. 

 

3. Key Functionalities of Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management

3.1. Plan Ahead with Confidence: Time-Dependent Hierarchies

The ability to plan hierarchy changes in advance is a foundational benefit of the Universal Hierarchy Framework provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which SAP Revenue Growth Management now supports. Unlike traditional hierarchies where updates take effect immediately, the Universal Hierarchy Framework allows system admins or KAMs to define validity periods for both customer and product hierarchies. This means users can plan and schedule entire hierarchy changes‚Äîsuch as a sales region reorganization or a new product category introduction‚Äîwell in advance, with changes becoming effective automatically on a specified date.

  • Proactive Workflow Alignment

According to user research, portfolio reviews and hierarchy changes are typically planned months in advance. With the Universal Hierarchy Framework, users can set up all necessary changes far in advance for the next planning year‚Äîand avoid end-of-year rushes before the holiday season, directly aligning system updates with strategic business cycles.

  • Reduced Operational Risk

By allowing changes to be scheduled and automatically activated, system admins and KAMs significantly reduce the risk of errors or missed updates during critical periods, ensuring that planning and execution always reflect the intended future organizational reality.

 

3.2. Unified View: Managing Multi‚ÄëVersion Product Hierarchies in a Single Screen

Businesses rarely operate on a single, fixed product hierarchy version for a long period of time. The Universal Hierarchy Framework recognizes this reality by supporting multiple time‚Äëbound product hierarchy versions. SAP Revenue Growth Management introduces a unified view ‚Äî a one‚Äëscreen user experience that presents all relevant hierarchy versions on a single screen. This allows KAMs to view and select products or categories across different hierarchy versions without switching contexts, ensuring a complete and continuous planning overview.

One-Screen Transparency

  • Workflow: For example, in a 2026 ready meals account plan, ‚Äúsalad‚Äù belongs to product hierarchy A (PH A) in the first half of the year, and ‚Äúpizza‚Äù is introduced in the latter half under product hierarchy B (PH B). When a KAM plans a promotion for both items, they need to access them on one screen.
  • A Unified View: By default, the UI primarily displays the earliest valid hierarchy version (e.g. PH A) for the selected planning period. Users are notified that multiple hierarchy versions are available and can switch between versions on the same page. This one-screen view, validated by user research, reduces navigation effort and prevents confusion associated with managing disjointed views.

 

 

Uninterrupted Focus for Informed Business Decisions

  • Workflow: If a KAM views PH B, which excludes "salad", they can still find "salad" in the Product Categories in Other Versions section. When the KAM selects ‚Äúsalad‚Äù and switches to PH A where "salad" exists, the UI keeps the selection valid, allowing planning to continue without interruption.
  • Informed Decision-Making: KAMs can identify changes and understand where products sit in the hierarchy structure during a given planning period, providing valuable context for business decisions.
  • Uninterrupted Planning: Product selection remains valid when switching between versions, reducing toggling and keeping KAMs focused on planning tasks.

 

 

3.3. Streamlined Selection: The Fully Expanded Flat List

When users need speed and efficiency‚Äîespecially for customer selection‚Äîa flat list that presents all available options at a single, non-nested level, is often more effective than a tree structure. In SAP Revenue Growth Management, customer selection uses a fully expanded flat list to speed search and selection.

  • Quick, Effortless Navigation

KAMs looking for a specific customer no longer need to drill down through multiple tree structures. In promotion planning, choosing correct customers quickly is often more critical than understanding the full customer tree. With the flat list, KAMs can search, filter, select, and continue‚Äîkeeping focus on core planning objectives. This simplification is backed by user research and aligns with natural user behavior.

  • All Options Expanded at Fingertips

Within SAP Revenue Growth Management, flat lists are presented fully expanded by default, enabling users to see all selectable items at once. This creates a simple, efficient experience and is accompanied by search and filter capabilities for productivity.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Shape Universal Hierarchy Management

The introduction of Universal Hierarchy Framework is a significant step in enabling customers on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to utilize SAP Revenue Growth Management. By providing time-dependent hierarchies, unified multi-version views, and streamlined selection experiences, we aim to help emerging small and medium-sized companies in the consumer product industry to stay agile and competitive in a rapidly changing market.

If you're an existing or a prospective customer of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you're more than welcome to join our co-innovation for Universal Hierarchies. Contact us today at RGM_Engage@sap.com to start the journey toward modernizing your trade promotion management and embracing a more agile approach to planning.

 

Final Note: The support for Universal Hierarchies in SAP Revenue Growth Management is scheduled to become available in January 2026, in support of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Secure your spot as a co-innovation partner today and let‚Äôs drive your revenue growth.

 

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

    • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
    • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management‚Äôs Account Plan
    • Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management 
    • Driving Promotion Excellence: Streamlined Creation and Copying with SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Financial Execution & Claims for Trade Promotions with SAP Revenue Growth Management & SAP Cloud ERP
    • Master Your KPIs: How SAP Revenue Growth Management Boosts Data-Driven Growth 
    • Modernize Planning: Universal Hierarchy in SAP Revenue Growth Management for SAP Cloud ERP Customers

entry.title: Re: Adding where condition in CDS extension
entry.content:
Good day @dhina_007

The public cloud does not allow you to link your custom CDS view to replace the data source of any Fiori app (in your case Display Line Items in General Ledger). So, you cannot swap them in public cloud because they are pre-delivered.

What you can do depends on what your goal is.

There are a few options you may consider:

  • Is to use the standard filter and save a variant if you only need the filter
  • Is to try key user UI adaptation if Document Type is not offered in the filter bar
  • Build your own app or report and publish it as a tile.

What exactly is your goal?

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Date Is Technically Correct‚Ä¶ but HR Is Still Not Happy
entry.content:
‚ÄúThe Date Is Technically Correct‚Ä¶ but HR Is Still Not Happy‚Äù

A Practical How-To for Resignation and Last Working Date Logic in SAP SuccessFactors EC

It usually starts with a resignation case that looks harmless.

The system shows a date.
Payroll confirms the calculation.
Technically, everything is correct.

And then HR says:

‚ÄúThis is not how resignations work in real life.‚Äù

If you‚Äôve implemented SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, you‚Äôve heard this before. Especially during UAT. Especially when exits, notice periods, and payroll deadlines are involved.

This how-to article explains how to fix one of the most common ‚Äî and most underestimated ‚Äî gaps in EC:
Date of Resignation and Last Working Date logic when time, weekends, and notice periods collide.

 

Why This Problem Shows Up in Almost Every EC Project

Out of the box, Employee Central treats dates exactly as dates.

  • A resignation submitted on Sunday is still Sunday
  • A resignation submitted at 6:31 PM is still ‚Äútoday‚Äù
  • A notice period end date can land on a weekend without any warning

From a system point of view, nothing is wrong.
From a business point of view, this causes confusion, rework, and manual overrides.

HR teams think in:

  • Working days
  • Office cut-off times
  • Payroll processing realities

This how-to focuses on aligning system logic with business reality.

 

Business Requirement (What We Are Solving)

Date of Resignation (DOR)

  • If an employee submits resignation after 6:30 PM IST, the system should consider the next working day as the effective Date of Resignation.
  • If an employee submits resignation on Saturday or Sunday, the system should automatically move the Date of Resignation to the first working day.

Last Working Date (LWD) as per Notice Period

  • LWD should be calculated as:
    Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice (calendar days)
  • If the calculated LWD falls on a weekend, it should move to the next working day.

 

System Assumptions (Critical)

Before building the rules, confirm the following:

  • Module: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
  • System Locale: EN_US
  • Business Time Zone: IST
  • Working Days: Monday to Friday
  • Working Hours Cut-off: 18:30 IST
  • Notice Period Type: Calendar days

Even though the system locale is EN_US, resignation timing must follow IST working hours.
This detail is often missed ‚Äî and causes most after-hours issues.

 

Solution Design (Recommended Approach)

To keep the logic stable and easy to explain during UAT, the solution is split into two independent EC Business Rules:

  1. Date of Resignation Adjustment Rule
  2. Last Working Date as per Notice Period Rule

Each rule has a clear responsibility and does not interfere with the other.

 

Rule 1: Adjust Date of Resignation

(After Hours & Weekend Handling)

Purpose

Ensure the effective Date of Resignation always falls on a working day.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Field: Date of Resignation

Logic Overview

  1. Convert system DateTime to IST using UTC offset (5.5).
  2. If time is on or after 18:30 IST, shift DOR to the next day.
  3. Check day of week:
    • Saturday ‚Üí add 2 days
    • Sunday ‚Üí add 1 day

Outcome

The system stores a business-valid Date of Resignation, not just the submission date.

 

 

Rule 2: Calculate Last Working Date as per Notice Period

Purpose

Calculate LWD correctly and prevent it from falling on a weekend.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Trigger Fields:
    • Date of Resignation
    • Required Days of Notice

Step 1: Provisional LWD

Provisional LWD = Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice

This uses calendar days, as defined by policy.

Step 2: Weekend Validation

  • Saturday ‚Üí add 2 days
  • Sunday ‚Üí add 1 day
  • Weekday ‚Üí no change

Outcome

The final Last Working Date as per Notice Period always lands on a working day.

 

 

 

 

Important Detail: How Notice Period Is Counted

This is where most confusion happens.

In SuccessFactors:

  • When you add calendar days, the Date of Resignation is already included.

Example

  • Effective Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Required Days of Notice: 45

Correct system result:

  • Last Working Date = 28-Jan-2026

Adding one extra day here would be incorrect.

 

End-to-End Test Scenario

Input

  • Date of Resignation entered: 14-Dec-2025 (Sunday)
  • Required Days of Notice: 45
  • Submission time: After 6:30 PM IST

System Result

  1. Effective DOR ‚Üí 15-Dec-2025 (Monday)
  2. Provisional LWD ‚Üí 28-Jan-2026
  3. Weekend check ‚Üí Not required

Final Values

  • Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Last Working Date as per NP: 28-Jan-2026

 

 

Rule Assignment Summary

Rule

Field

Execution

DOR Adjustment Rule

Date of Resignation

On Change

LWD Calculation Rule

Last Working Date as per NP

On Change

This sequencing avoids circular updates and ensures consistent behaviour.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Normalize Date of Resignation first
  • Separate resignation timing logic from notice period logic
  • EN_US locale does not imply US working hours
  • Weekend handling must be explicit in EC
  • Small date errors create big HR trust issues

 

Closing Note

Resignation logic is one of those areas where the system is judged not by its features, but by its judgment.

When dates behave the way HR expects, no one notices.
When they don‚Äôt, everyone does.

Getting this right is less about complex configuration and more about understanding how business actually works.

entry.title: Re: Managing Vehicles in SAP Asset Management and SAP SSAM
entry.content:
Greetings,

you culd look into SAP fleet management solution:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e98c7c41bbe8439e90daa5c114a7573b/0e7bbb53707db44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US

It includes some additional functionalioties such as automatic fuel consumtion etc.

But overall vehicles are no different than any other equipment. You need to define which EAM processes are relevant for this type of technical object and explore the possibilities in scope of standard EAM functionalities (preventive, corrective, reactive, ...).

You would want to separate these objects by special equipment type, store additional data in a class and classify the individual equipment and you probably also want to have counters to track kilometers and trigger preventive maintenance based on that.

Best regards, M.

entry.title: Disable Open story button for SendNotification API in SAC.

entry.title: Re: Transformation from DTAZV to pain 001.001.09 New EBS...
entry.content:
Solution: After applying the note(2253571), you may still encounter errors when validating the XML file using the bank‚Äôs validator. These errors are usually related to specific XML tags that do not fully match the bank‚Äôs required format.

To address this, additional customizing in DMEE is required. Adjust or map the XML tags that are causing validation errors according to the bank‚Äôs specifications. Once the DMEE tree is aligned with the bank requirements, the XML file should pass the validation successfully.

entry.title: SAP Learning Practice System Stuck on ‚ÄúPlease wait, session is preparing ‚Äù ‚Äì How to Fix It
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre following the SAP Learning  Basic ABAP Programming course or trying to use the SAP BTP ABAP Environment practice system, you might encounter this frustrating issue:

‚ùå‚ÄúPlease wait, session is preparing‚Äù
‚ùåSession keeps loading and never starts

I ran into this myself, so here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening and how to fix it.

What‚Äôs the Problem?

SAP provides a preconfigured practice system for ABAP courses.
This system already contains the data and configuration needed to:

  • Complete exercises from Basic ABAP Programming

  • Experiment with SAP BTP ABAP Environment

However, if your local setup or project connection is incorrect, the session may never finish loading.

Common Reasons Why This Happens

1Ô∏è‚É£Eclipse + ADT Tools Are Not Installed Correctly

To work with the ABAP practice system, you must have:

  • Eclipse IDE installed

  • ABAP Development Tools (ADT) plugin added

üìåSAP‚Äôs official installation guide:
üëâhttps://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-install-adt.html

If ADT is missing or outdated, the session will fail silently.

2Ô∏è‚É£Wrong ABAP Service Instance URL (Very Common ‚ùó)

This was the main issue in my case.

When creating an ABAP Cloud Project, Eclipse asks for:

  • ABAP service instance URL

‚ö†Ô∏èIf you accidentally use:

  • An ABAP service URL from your own SAP BTP Trial account

üëâThe SAP Learning practice session will get stuck on ‚ÄúPlease wait, session is loading‚Äù.

‚úÖThe Correct Solution

‚úîÔ∏èStep 1: Use the Provided Practice System URL

When you enrolled in the SAP Learning course, you downloaded a file (usually):

  • s4d_ConfigFile

  • it Includes a README file

üìåInside that README, you‚Äôll find the correct ABAP service instance URL
üëâThis URL is specifically linked to the SAP Learning practice system

‚úîÔ∏èStep 2: Create a NEW ABAP Cloud Project

  • Open Eclipse

  • Create a new ABAP Cloud Project

  • Paste the ABAP service instance URL from the README

  • Do NOT use your own BTP trial URL

Once I did this, the session loaded immediately. ‚úÖ

 

At the end, you will see that the cloud project willl be added

entry.title: Re: Does the "Menu" button in the tab strip not fire chan...
entry.content:
Hi,

events are only fired for actions which cause an interaction with the application (server).
"Cancel" will cause a roundtrip to the application - SAP GUI sending the respective vKey to the server and the application reacts accordingly. However, all options from the menu which are not related to the application, but to SAP GUI itself (like calling options dialog) do not cause events and do not have to, because this is pure SAP GUI stuff which cannot be automated via SAP GUI Scripting anyway and which does not need any interaction with the application.

Best regards,
Frank

entry.title: Re: Integrate My Inbox link to SAP Flexible Workflow E-Mail notification
entry.content:
Hello, 

I think from an Clean Extensibility perspective, it is not recommended to extend C_WORKFLOWTASK. It is used in many standard templates and the End User Text label indicates it as: "DEPRECATED: Work item with text info" (as of S4 PCE 2023 FPS03)

Instead I would follow the recommendation in SAP note 3115396 and create an application-specific e-mail template based on my own CDS view. 

In SE80, you can create you own e-mail template, define your CDS view and set in Eclipse + ADT the API state to C1 released. Then your e-mail template will show up in the FIORI app for E-Mail templates as predelivered template and you can take it from there. 

Note to set the API state, only click once in the Eclipse-tree on it (In case you double click, then it opens in the Eclipse integrated GUI and it will not show the API state in Properties). 

Best regards,
Stefan

entry.title: Re: Syntax error snote
entry.content:
My answer is generic to any problem when installing a note with SNOTE:

  1. SNOTE automatically retrieves all the prerequisite SAP notes.
  2. Make sure you applied the manual instructions indicated in the SAP notes.
  3. Make sure you have installed all the SAP notes related to SNOTE (in case there's a bug with SNOTE).
  4. It may happen, but it's rare, that there's a problem with very recent SAP notes. In that case, contact SAP Support.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA SQL Script : substring the string
entry.content:
You could use SUBSTRING_REGEXPR function. Here is an example

WITH MyDummyData AS (
    SELECT '1/22' AS input_string FROM DUMMY
    UNION ALL
    SELECT '221/22/333/4444' AS input_string FROM DUMMY
)
SELECT 
    input_string,
    SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('[^/]+$' IN input_string) AS extracted_value
FROM MyDummyData

entry.title: Need access to reporting section in SAP for Me to view the utilization of licenses and resources
entry.content:
To access Reporting - SAP for Me, it is necessary for your S-user to have the "Display Support Situation Reporting" authorization. 

Here are the steps to request the appropriate authorization:  

How to request an S-user authorization: 

Contact your Super Administrators to assign you the required authorizations on the correct level. If you don't know the administrators at your company, visit Access and Authorizations (part "Who is my administrator?"). Alternatively use the Self-Service Authorization Request as documented in KBA‚ÄØ2891528. After you submit your request, the Super administrator will only need to approve it.

For additional details, you may refer to the documentation in KBA 3336856 - How to access Customer Insights Dashboard - SAP for Me

If you have any further questions or need additional assistance, please let me know.  

Best Regards,  
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automatic Payment Run Identification in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Jessica,

In the document generated for the payment e.g. 2000000xxx will have the following information in the header text: 20251112-RUN05, where the payment run date is the date 12th of Nov 2025 and run ID is RUN05. This is system generated string in the document generated during payment run. Hope this helps you to identify the string based which you can reconcile the payments. Let us know if helps or you have further query.

Regards.

entry.title: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Motivation

In my previous blog I explained the Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting and when it needs adjustment by customers.

In this blog I will explain how to copy and adjust the underlying analytical queries and adjust the selection to prepare them for a customized review booklet. It is for key users and technical consultants.

Since we did enhancements in the booklet with SAP Cloud ERP 2602, as announced in the previous blog, we had to create new analytical queries, which I will already use in my screenshots. I recommend to wait for 2602 to do the adjustments, so you already have the new features for several company codes and currencies in your customized booklet.

Copying the SAP delivered queries

Launch the App ‚ÄúCustom Analytical Queries and Services‚Äù (F1572A) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST. Click on the link ‚ÄúManage Queries‚Äù. In the next screen click the button ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù.

Figure 1: Copy the first SAP delivered query 

In the pop-up, name your custom query, e.g. ‚ÄúYY1_CUSTCOMPMARG‚Äù and as the source query specify ‚ÄúC_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2‚Äù (for 2602 release, in 2508 it would be C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY).

This query is used on the ‚ÄúCompany Margin (Full Year)‚Äù page group of the booklet.

Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù and on the next screen give your new customer query a name, e.g. ‚ÄúCompany Margin Custom Query‚Äù.

Figure 2: Name custom query

 Then click on the ‚ÄúFields‚Äù tab.

Figure 3: Optionally add a remove fields

Here you can optionally add or remove fields in the query to be used or not in the booklet.

The list of available fields comes from the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 (in 2602, or I_CompanyMarginCube in 2508) and can only be changed by SAP.

If you also want the ‚ÄúYear-to-Date‚Äù, ‚ÄúFiscal Quarter‚Äù or ‚ÄúFiscal Period‚Äù comparison page groups, which are available in the SAP delivered booklet, in you customized booklet, please repeat the steps above for the SAP delivered query ‚ÄúC_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY_2‚Äù (in 2602, or C_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY in 2508) after completing the following steps for the first query.

 

Figure 4: Copy the second SAP delivered query 

 

Adjusting the selection criteria in the custom query

Next click on the tab ‚ÄúModel‚Äù. You will see the list of measures (or key figures) used in the booklet.

As explained in the previous blog, you need to adjust the selection of Read Key Figures, if you do not use the SAP best practices Functional Areas.

But let‚Äôs first see the usage of the semantic tags on the Read Key Figures.

Select e.g. the measure ‚ÄúBilled Revenue (technical name ‚ÄúBilledRevenueAmntInDispCrry‚Äù). Then turn on ‚ÄúSematic Tag‚Äù selection criteria. 

Figure 5: Sematic Tag selection of Read Key Figure

 You will see, that the semantic tag ‚ÄúBILL_REV‚Äù is used to read billed revenues. Please do not change this.

Now you can go through the list of Read Key Figures to decide, where the Functional Area selection needs to be adjusted.

Figure 6: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

 As an example, let‚Äôs take ‚ÄúCost of Goods Sold ‚Äì Variable‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúVariableCOGSAmntInDispCrry‚Äù). Select the measure from the list and activate ‚ÄúFunctional Area‚Äù selection criteria. 

Figure 7: Change Functional Area selection for COGS

 You see the SAP best practices Functional Areas YB18 (Cost of Goods Sold) and YB25 (Consulting/Services) are used to read COGS for product or service centric business processes.

You can now change them to the ones you use in your respective sales scenarios.

Figure 8: Add Functional Area selection

 The same applies for the measure ‚ÄúCost of Goods Sold ‚Äì Fixed‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúFxdCOGSAmtInDspCrcy‚Äù.

 As another example let‚Äôs take the measure ‚ÄúAdministration Overhead‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúAdminOverheadAmtInDspCrcy‚Äù).

In the SAP delivered query the Functional Area YB40 is used for Administration. You can now replace with your own.

Figure 9: Replace Functional Area selection

Please complete this task for all measures, which need adjustment of Functional Area.

If you have copied the query for the period comparison pages, please do the same there. It contains the same measure structure.

 

Optional: Change default values for filters and parameters

The query also contains same default values for general selection in the booklet. You can optionally change them, so the apply for all users in your customized booklet.

For example, if you want to use your own Financial Statement Version (please see previous blog), go on the tab ‚ÄúParameters‚Äù, select the ‚ÄúFinancial Statement Version‚Äù and change the default value. 

Figure 10: Change default values of parameters

 Please note, that the FSV can stay a filter in the booklet and can later be changed by an end user again.

 Another example is to change the default value of the global filter ‚ÄúCurrency Field‚Äù, which is introduced in 2602.

Go on the tab ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù and select ‚ÄúCurrency Field‚Äù. The default value is Company Code Currency (CCC). You can change e.g. to Global Currency (GC).

Figure 11: Change default values of filters 

 

Check and publish your custom queries

In the next step please go to the tab ‚ÄúLogs‚Äù and click the button ‚ÄúCheck‚Äù.

No errors should appear in the logs and you can click ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù.

Figure 12: Publish custom query

 Please repeat for second query.

 

Create InA Service with both customer queries

The custom booklet will require an InA Service which contain the custom queries.

To create it, go back to the start page of the App ‚ÄúCustom Analytical Queries and Services‚Äù (F1572A) and click ‚ÄúManage InA Services‚Äù, then click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

Figure 13: Create custom InA Service

 Give it a name, a label and click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Next add your custom queries to it with ‚ÄúAdd query‚Äù and publish the service. 

Figure 14: Add custom queries

 

Create custom review booklet

You can now create your own review booklet based on the InA Service.

Please launch the App ‚ÄúManage KPIs and Reports‚Äù (F2814) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.

Select the tab ‚ÄúReview Booklets‚Äù and click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù. 

Figure 15: Create review booklet.

Give it an ID, a name and description and click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù. 

Figure 16: Open configuration for custom review booklet

 Now click ‚ÄúOpen Configuration‚Äù to access the review booklet designer. On the tab ‚ÄúGeneral‚Äù specify your custom Ina Service. 

Figure 17: Add custom Ina Service in custom review booklet

 Then click ‚ÄúGenerate Content‚Äù, select your custom queries and click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù. 

Figure 18: Generate booklet content for customer queries

This will prepare the data providers for the booklet.

You now can go through the booklet designer and customize your pages groups, pages, row and column sets, etc.

Please see the SAP help how to work with the review booklet designer: Configuring a Review Booklet

This is a manual step, which can‚Äôt be avoided by coping the SAP delivered review booklet, since all settings in the review booklet designer depend on the used queries.

You can however have a look at the SAP delivered booklet as a reference how to configure yours.

Figure 19: Reference Business Pages in SAP delivered booklet

 

Conclusion

You now know, how to customize a query and create a custom review booklet on top of it.

With this know-how you can also customize other SAP delivered review booklets.

The article can also give you an idea, how to create your complete own custom analytical queries, using developer extensibility. This is more advanced and would allow you to create an own contribution margin structure with more than 3 levels and different key figures for revenues and costs.

You can also create review booklet on top of self-developed custom analytical queries.

 

More Information on SAP Cloud ERP:

  • Finance Collection Blog (roadmap, quarterly release highlights, microlearnings) here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Customer Community for Finance here
  • What‚Äôs New here
  • Help Portal Product Page here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition release info here
  • SAP S/4HANA PSCC Digital Enablement Wheel here
  • Early Release Webinar Series here
  • Inside SAP S/4HANA Podcast here
  • Best practices for SAP S/4HANA Cloud here
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Community: here
  • Feature Scope Description here
  • OpenSAP Microlearnings for SAP S/4HANA for Finance and GRC here

entry.title: Re: How can I maintain restrictions on Block/Unblock in S...
entry.content:
Hi,

Block/Unblock feature is basic and mandatory activity, there is no option to restrict it if you have access to the app for data monitor.

After you run a task successfully, you have to block it and also you cannot close a period until you have unblocked task.

Regards.

entry.title: Re: Create A/R credit memo based on paid (closed) A/R inv...
entry.content:
There is a solution in native SAP Business One for this.

- Navigate to the AR Invoice 

- In the main menu choose Data > Advanced > Change Document Status to Open 

-> You can now copy the invoice to a Credit Note 

The previous payment received and reconciliation remain intact in this process. 

Hope this helps.

entry.title: Re: Sales order creation from cxml document
entry.content:
@Meriadec wrote:

Hello,

We have one customer who is using a P2P solution which is able to send his purchase order as PO Cxml message. The objective is to create a sales document (sales order or sales quotation #S4/HANA SD#) using this cxml document.

I know we can deliver using ABAP code but I didn't find any standard way to proceed. I have even looked into SAP Business Network but resources related to sell side is not clear. 

Have I missed something ?

Hello @Meriadec,
There‚Äôs no standard S/4HANA SD function to directly consume cXML POs into sales orders ‚Äî it requires custom integration. Typically you‚Äôd parse the cXML via middleware (SAP CPI/PI) or ABAP service, then map to SD BAPIs/IDocs (e.g. `ORDERS05`). SAP Business Network focuses on buy‚Äëside; for sell‚Äëside you need custom mapping or 3rd‚Äëparty connectors.

Best Regards,
Mabel Brown

entry.title: Get to know SAP‚Äôs educational offerings for academia
entry.content:
SAP offers an integrated suite of solutions that help organizations of all sizes and industries run their entire business‚Äîfrom finance and supply chain to customer experience and sustainability. The SAP University Alliances portfolio of academic offerings mirror the SAP solution portfolio, providing access to the latest SAP technologies and academically relevant content to lecturers in disciplines across business, information systems, engineering and computer science. The portfolio helps lecturers connect theory to practice in a way that meets their academic need, whether it is content supporting a full semester course or smaller chunks of content students can complete outside of class in a flipped classroom model.

The challenge (and opportunity!) is to identify the offerings that support your own classroom learning objectives and teaching style. To make our portfolio easier to understand and consume, we‚Äôve started to restructure and simplify. We‚Äôve aligned our offerings into a framework that features both no cost resources and learning experiences direct to lecturers around the world plus the low-cost offers with premium support from our University Competence Centers (UCCs) / Academic Competence Centers (UCCs) and other academic partners that have anchored our portfolio for more than 25 years.

Offerings are now clustered into four topic areas, each lead by a teaching offering manager (TOM) that can connect the dots between the academic topic and relevant SAP solution(s).

The four topic areas are:

  1. Business Process Management
    - Executing, modeling and transforming business processes from sales to purchasing, production, human resources and financial reporting

  2. Data Science & Analytics
    - Develop future data analysts / data architects, and data literacy for all students

  3. App Development & Coding
    - low-code and pro-code development, AI and other critical topics tomorrow‚Äôs technology leaders need experience with

  4. Computing Education
    - introduces computer science concepts and provide a first programming experience with the visual, block-based Snap! Programming language

Announcing!  New portfolio blog series

To ensure our academic community is always in the loop with new and updated offerings, we are launching this new blog series. Each topic leader has published their first blog providing a big picture introduction to the topic area and its key offerings, best practices shared by lecturers, how to get started, content in the pipeline and much more.  Each quarter they will share the latest updates so you can start exploring the new / updated resources and plan your classroom activities.

Call to Action:  Join the discussion!

Read the topic area blogs, subscribe and join the discussion.  Post your questions and ideas. Share your experiences and best practices.  Let us know how we can help you be successful using SAP in the classroom!

entry.title: Re: Output Management - How to send emails to mail-addres...
entry.content:
Hello @SCHNEIDERT

Thank you for your question

You are correct, no released CDS view provides exactly what you described. So yes, the approach is to create a Custom CDS View based on standard data.

First, I would suggest you avoid using I_BPContactToFuncAndDept unless you need to filter function or department. It might be an overkill just for emails and could introduce duplicates which you already observed.

Second, using I_BPRelationship_2 provides relationship between Customer and Contact Person. The I_BusinessPartnerContactAddress will provide the actual email address which you can then join using the BusinessPartner2 from I_BPRelationship_2

Third, you are getting duplicates probably because some of your BPs have multiple address versions for each valid date, you did not apply StandardAddress filter or you are joining both directions of the BP1 to BP2 relationship. I suggest you only include BUR001 Contact Person, IsStandardAddress and filter out ValidTo entries.

Below are steps you can consider in your tenant:

Open your Custom CDS View app, create a new

Set the primary data source as shown in the screen below

Add Business partner as an associated data source.

Make use of: I_BusinessPartnerAddress and thereafter, join I_BPCompanRelationshipVH. BusinessPartner2=I_BusinessPartnerAddress.BusinessPartener.  Make sure you IsStandardAddress is set to true.

Then publish your CDS View.

You can test it with the Custom Analytical Queries

The YY1_I_BPRelationship_2 works same for your use case. You can select fields like BP1, BP2, Emailaddress, Relationship Category. You may also add filters as mentioned earlier.

A Pseudo CDS View code could look like this:

Finally, regarding your question on how the Code in the BAdI would look like, I do not have the authorisation in the system to provide such information. You can however, implement the BAdI APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS in the output Parameter Determination.

To summarise:

  • Yes, you need a Custom CDS View
  • Use the BP2 plus BPContactAddress as your base
  • Use filtering to avoid duplicates
  • In your BAdI, select business partner as a selection from your CDS view

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP RAP Application ‚Äì Data Not Inserting into Custom Tables (First RAP Project)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am currently working on my first SAP RAP application in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I need guidance from experienced RAP developers.

Business Requirement

Create an Excel uploader to update Bank Details for Vendor/Customer master data.

What I Have Implemented So Far

I followed the standard RAP development steps:

  1. Created Custom Persistent Tables and Draft Tables

  2. Created Interface CDS View

  3. Created Consumption CDS View

  4. Added Metadata Extensions for UI

  5. Defined Behavior Definitions for Interface and Consumption Views

  6. Implemented Behavior Handler Classes

  7. Created Service Definition

  8. Created Service Binding

Current Issue

  • I am successfully reading Excel data and storing it into an internal table in the behavior implementation class.

  • However, when I try to insert this data into my custom item table, no data is getting persisted in the database.

  • There are no syntax errors, but the records are not saved.

My Doubt / Confusion

Since this is my first RAP project, I am not sure:

  • Whether I am inserting data in the correct RAP lifecycle method

  • If I should use MODIFY ENTITIES instead of direct INSERT

  • If the issue is related to managed behavior, draft handling, or association (_item) handling

  • Or if my behavior definition and class implementation are not aligned

Request for Help

I would really appreciate if someone could:

  • Review my approach

  • Point out what I might be doing wrong

  • Explain the correct way to persist item data in a RAP-managed scenario

  • Share best practices for Excel upload + RAP persistence

I will paste all relevant code (CDS, Behavior Definition, and Class Implementation) below for reference.

Thank you very much in advance for your support.

Please paste your Code recommendation if possible.

Environment:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Extensibility 
RAP (Managed with Draft)

entry.title: S4HC Public Crosscompany Flow CO Issue (Margin analysis by customer not available at group level)
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We are implementing S4HC Public to a Industrial Food company. They have a manufacturing company (2000) and a trading company (3000). They have a crosscompany process, in which the shipment is done from 2000 and the billing from 3000, so there is an internal billing with a margin because of legal transfer price requirements. Once the flow is done and the accounting documents are registered, the analytical PL by company code is shown in the screenshot attached. 

The problem we find is that the customer filled in the PSG of the expense registered in 3000 (internal billing) is the final customer instead of the group customer (3000), whereas the COGS from the shipment from 2000 has the group customer (3000) instead of the final customer. This standard behaviour of the system prevents the client to analyze the actual margin by customer at group level skipping the internal billing, since the revenue is allocated to the final customer in the PSG, but the COGS from the shipment is allocated to the group customer (3000).

- Implementing transfer pricing is not an option.

- Changing the invoice type from INVOICE02 to INVOICE01 in the IDOC, so that internal billing expense is allocated to the group customer (3000) in the PSG is not allowed in S4HC Public.

- PSG derivation customizing point (which would resolve our problem, since we could change the customer in the PSG according to many conditions and rules) is not available in S4HC Public. Instead we have a very limited app (Manage Substitution and Validation Rules) in which, for the Margin Analysis context, we only have available PSG characteristics as conditions (which are not useful for this case) and fields like gl account or movement type (needed for doing the derivation correctly) are not available.

WHAT CAN WE DO? Is there any custom logic we can use for an "advanced PSG characteristic sustitution"? 

Thanks. Regards,

entry.title: Re: How to avoid errors when configuring mandatory event reason for Onboarding?
entry.content:
Is anyone having an issue with Rehire Event reason?

Our Rehire cases are triggering an error - You cannot create a job information record without the hire record for user. The first job information record must be the hire record

As event reason is mandatory in offer, when onboarding is initiated and upon submission of the Review New Hire data step, the error is triggered - You cannot create a job information record without the hire record for user. The first job information record must be the hire record

entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities
entry.content:
Since 1H 2025, SAP has released the new Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities. The purpose of this blog is to describe it, showcase it in action, and highlight its main features beyond what the official documentation covers.

 

What Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities is NOT

Before diving in let's clarify what Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA) is not: do not confuse it with the previous version called Payroll Control Center: Process Management.

Although both are related and focused on the same process they are different solutions with a different approach, being PCC-MPA far more powerful and easier to configure. It includes all the functionalities of its predecessor, plus much more.

 

What's Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities

Now, let's define what it really is. Here a definition extracted from the official guide (quoted verbatim; all copied text in this blog is in italic):

The Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities‚Äã solution enables business users to manage a complete payroll cycle from start to end, not just running the payroll calculation, but all payroll activities that are necessary (for example, all statutory reporting, internal reporting, and so on).

In Manage Payroll Activities, the payroll activity list provides a graphical overview of all payroll activities in a graph. From this graph, the payroll manager can already get a good understanding of the relationship between the different payroll activities and the quality of the overall payroll cycle.

The payroll manager clicks a payroll activity to investigate its details, for example, a Monitoring activity. A monitoring activity allows users to get early insight into the payroll data quality.

Clicking a step opens a customizable dashboard that has been configured by the configuration user and shows the relevant information that enables the payroll manager to judge if their payroll data quality is good.

The payroll manager can click a dashboard card to see further details. They can drill down to the details they want (which can be customized). The payroll manager can check the open alerts, check who is working on the alerts, and further drill down to the details of an alert to get an understanding of its complexity.

In the Manage Alerts app, the payroll administrators can do some detailed analysis of why an employee has a specific problem. The app provides a dashboard view where the payroll administrators can get a quick understanding of the situation. The payroll administrator can click a dashboard card to see further details. They can drill down to the details they want based on the configuration.

 

Sound great, right?

Before we get into it, let's review the prerequisites.

 

Prerequisites

As pointed out here, these are its prerequisites:

  • You have implemented your payroll.
  • Your payroll is based on SAP Human Capital Management for SAP S/4 HANA solutions.
  • If you are implementing SAP preferred payroll solution, that is SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll, you must to enable it in Provisioning selecting Enable Payroll Control Center checkbox.

Common question:  Does it work in other SAP Human Capital Management for SAP S/4 HANA solutions, such as Private Cloud Edition? 

Answer: Yes, but future enhancements and new features related to PCC-MPA, may be exclusive to SAP's preferred solution: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll. That is why all the references in this guide to official documentation point to it. 

 

Key concepts

Here a list of the most important objects in the solution:

  • action: A dynamic URL that can generate the value at run time and points to a link where payroll administrators or payroll manager can update employees' master data or check further details.
  • activity: The sequence of all steps that are required to execute payroll and all related activities (for example, legal reporting) for a specific entity.
  • activity list: The combination of one or more relevant payroll activities in a complete payroll cycle.
  • analytics designer: Program output, table layout, simple form of label-value pairs, or different types of charts to provide details for a validation rule or step execution.
  • step: A single step within a payroll activity.
  • policy: A set of validation rules grouped according to your needs. A policy helps you to achieve payroll compliance.
  • validation rule: A check function executed by the system to identify compliance violations or potential risks.

 

Solution Insights

Let's see it in action!

 

1. Configure your Payroll Activities

Use a graphical and user-friendly configuration tool to set define payroll activities tailored to your specific process.

You will be able to define your process, with all the activities and steps, setting the prerequisites, automating them when possible, define run periods and much more:

 

It is worth to mention that any report in your backend would be accessible to the PCC-MPA, that means that even your custom reports can be included without extra coding.

 

2. Plan your Payroll Activities

Once configured, you only need to start a new recurrence and the entire payroll process, with all the activities and their steps, will be ready to run:

 

 

3. Run and Monitor your Payroll 

Now the fun begins!

Run each step/activity and view its results with the charts, program outputs,... as you customized, tracking your process graphically in real time.

Also the monitor activity will show the preconfigured alerts that the system has calculated proactively:

 

 

4. Alerts Resolution

Each alert includes its own detailed insights: charts, employee data, lists, ... even specific resolution guides that you have set up beforehand to simplify administrators' tasks. They will be able to resolve any issue without leaving the Payroll Control Center!

 

 

 

What's next

Did you liked it? Stay tuned, more updates coming soon!
